abstract.p: Tax shield-bankruptcy cost models produce noncorner optimal capital structures by trading the tax shield of debt against expected bankruptcy costs. In this article, theoretical and empirical arguments regarding the magnitude and incidence of bankruptcy costs relative to the tax shield are reviewed; only if bankruptcy costs are sufficiently large to offset this shield do such models make sense. It is found that knowledge about bankruptcy costs and the tax shield on debt is insufficient to make a definitive judgment regarding their relative size. Therefore, the tax shield-bankruptcy cost system remains a potential approach to the capital structure problem.
